description: From Middle English undressen, equivalent to un- +‎ dress. Compare Old English unsċrȳdan (“to undress”, literally “un-shroud”).

entries.meaning: (now archaic or historical) Partial or informal dress for women, as worn in the home rather than in public.
(now archaic or historical) Informal clothing for men, as opposed to formal or ceremonial wear.
examples: His undress, and the agitation he was apparently in, which she imputed to the effect of her charms, combined to make him appear more interesting both to the mother and daughter  […] .

entries.meaning: Now more specifically, a state of having few or no clothes on.

verbs.description: undress (third-person singular simple present undresses, present participle undressing, simple past and past participle undressed)

examples: The doctor asked me to undress for the examination.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove the clothing of (someone). [from 17th c.]
examples: The young men slowly and sensually undressed each other before making passionate love.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To strip of something. [from 17th c.]
To take the dressing, or covering, from.
